mn46:1.1: The Buddha delves into this topic in more detail in [mn114]().
mn46:20.1: Rancid urine was the worst of medicines, used when nothing better was available. Specifically, the Vinaya allows it as a purgative in the case of snakebite ([pli-tv-kd6:14.6.4]()), and gives chebulic myrobalan soaked in cattle urine as a remedy for jaundice ([pli-tv-kd6:14.7.9]()). The Buddha was not a doctor, however, and modern research has shown that urine, far from being a sterile cure-all, contains [dangerous](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3032614/) levels of [bacterial pathogens](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3957746/) and has no  medicinal value.
